abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The ability of an insect to survive attack by natural enemies can be modulated by the presence of defensive symbionts. Study of aphid–symbiont–enemy interactions has indicated that protection may depend on the interplay of symbiont, host and attacking parasite genotypes. However, the importance of these interactions is poorly understood outside of this model system. Here, we study interactions within a <jats:italic>Drosophila</jats:italic> model system, in which <jats:italic>Spiroplasma</jats:italic> protect their host against parasitoid wasps and nematodes. We examine whether the strength of protection conferred by <jats:italic>Spiroplasma</jats:italic> to its host, <jats:italic>Drosophila melanogaster</jats:italic> varies with strain of attacking <jats:italic>Leptopilina heterotoma</jats:italic> wasp. We perform this analysis in the presence and absence of ethanol, an environmental factor that also impacts the outcome of parasitism. We observed that <jats:italic>Spiroplasma</jats:italic> killed all strains of wasp. However, the protection produced by <jats:italic>Spiroplasma</jats:italic> following wasp attack depended on wasp strain. A composite measure of protection, including both the chance of the fly surviving attack and the relative fecundity/fertility of the survivors, varied from a <4% positive effect of the symbiont following attack of the fly host by the Lh14 strain of wasp to 21% for the Lh-Fr strain in the absence of ethanol. We also observed that environmental ethanol altered the pattern of protection against wasp strains. These data indicate that the dynamics of the <jats:italic>Spiroplasma</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>Drosophila</jats:italic>–wasp tripartite interaction depend upon the genetic diversity within the attacking wasp population, and that prediction of symbiont dynamics in natural systems will thus require analysis across natural enemy genotypes and levels of environmental ethanol.</jats:p>
